hints.content: The arrow points to all values greater than $0$.
And the point at $0$ is *not* filled in.
So, the inequality represents everything strictly **greater than $0$.**

question.content:
**Choose the inequality that represents the following graph.**


[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A number line from negative 5 to 5 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. An open point is plotted at 0. A line running to the right starts at 0 and continues.

choices.clue:
The graph of $x < 0$ actually looks like this:

![A number line from negative 5 to 5 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. An open point is plotted at 0. A line running to the left starts at 0 and continues.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/3ba1eb5c568b51cf72b7640503adab75c7e20818)

The graph of $x \leq 0$ actually looks like this:

![A number line from negative 5 to 5 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A closed point is plotted at 0. A line running to the left starts at 0 and continues.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/312ed573d92a3039dbcc806d00d93dbba30ce0ae)

The graph of $x \geq 0$ actually looks like this:

![A number line from negative 5 to 5 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A closed point is plotted at 0. A line running to the right starts at 0 and continues.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/f62de34c65221fb73bfd3e3a2d657803de7978c3)
